title: ct.category theory - Subfunctor of representable is continuous
body: Given an object $A$ in a category $\mathcal{C}$ , the functor $Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A,-)$ is tautologically continuous i.e. limit-preserving. Let $F$ be a subfunctor of $Hom_{\mathcal{C}}(A,-)$ , is $F$ in general continuous? We might assume $F$ is fully-faithful if necessary. ct.category-theory Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jun 22, 2020 at 10:13 gregodom 319 1 1 silver badge 3 3 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 3 6 $\begingroup$ Take $\mathcal C$ a meet-semilattice. Not every sub-upper-set of a principal filter is a filter. $\endgroup$ მამუკა ჯიბლაძე –  მამუკა ჯიბლაძე 2020-06-22 10:25:00 +00:00 Commented Jun 22, 2020 at 10:25 $\begingroup$ It might be actually true for fully faithful $F$, since there are hardly any. What would be your example of a fully faithful subfunctor of a representable functor? $\endgroup$ მამუკა ჯიბლაძე –  მამუკა ჯიბლაძე 2020-06-23 05:45:01 +00:00 Commented Jun 23, 2020 at 5:45 $\begingroup$ @მამუკაჯიბლაძე I do have an example for the fully faithful $F$ but it seems not easy to describe in a few lines... Do you have a proof / reference that such $F$ is necessarily continuous?
